climbs.name: South Ridge
climbs.fa: 1995 ???  as climbed by H. Microys, M. Rosenberger, R. Hall , S. Matz (?)

content.description:
Neither Putnam (1975) nor Fox-Laurilla (1992) list the south ridge as having been climbed. FA of Mtn was apparently made in 1970 via the East Ridge, gaining the ridge from the Typee-Forecastle col and climbing "delightful slabs". The Northwest ridge was descended in 1974 to get to Peguod. 

How such an obvious ridge was (supposedly unclimbed) as late as 1995 tells you how infrequently this area is visited. 

Memory is a bit hazy, but I believe we slabbed across the far south end of the ridge and gained the ridge proper from its East side. The climbing was pleasant and views outstanding. I don't recall belaying, and the photo of us climbing one of the steeper pitches doesn't seem to show a rope, but I can't believe we didn't take one along.

We would have descended the same route.  



East of Houston Lake Camp. 

Rope "in case", "Alpine" sparse selection of gear - I'd guess larger stuff.

Looking up towards the north, with your back to Houston Lake, this peak's south ridge (together with Mt Pequod - 9750 ft) forms the right side of the glacial basin of Mt Moby Dick that drains into Houston Lake / Creek.

Do not confuse with Mt Foremast (8810 ft, 2865m )


Looking up towards the north, with your back to Houston Lake, this peak's south ridge (together with Mt Pequod - 9750 ft) forms the right side of the glacial basin of Mt Moby Dick that drains into Houston Lake / Creek.
